snippets.snippet_text: The purification of RyR1 Ca 2+ release channels in 1988 [ 4 ] and the subsequent discovery in 1991 of pathogenic RYR1 variants [ 5 ] led to the association of impaired Ca 2+ homeostasis with malignant hyperthermia (MH) susceptibility (MIM # 145600) [ 6 ]. MH is a potentially fatal disorder of skeletal muscle Ca 2+ regulation. MH episodes are triggered by exposure to certain volatile anesthetics (e.g., sevoflurane, desflurane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (succinylcholine). MH episodes are characterized by uncontrolled muscle hypermetabolism, with a clinical presentation including hypercapnia, sinus tachycardia, masseter muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia [ 5 , 7 ]. Guidelines from the European Malignant Hyperthermia Group (EMHG) and Malignant Hyperthermia Association of the United States (MHAUS) continue to inform the use of anesthetic drugs in individuals susceptible to MH [ 8 , 9 ]. snippets.snippet_text: Additional histopathological features of CCD include increased internal and central nuclei, presence of rods, minimal to moderate endomysial fibrosis, increased fatty tissue and connective tissue infiltration, Z-line streaming, sarcomeric disorganization, fiber size variation, and predominance of type 1 fibers [ 79 ]. 1960s: malignant hyperthermia In 1960, Michael Denborough and Roger Lovell described a case in which a young man nearly died following general anesthesia procedure with halothane for a compound fracture of the tibia and fibula [ 80 ]. There had been ten deaths attributable to general anesthesia, specifically ethyl chloride and ether, in the proband’s family. The pattern of inheritance was similar to an incomplete penetrant dominant gene or genes [ 81 ]. Available medical records showed that the course of events in the deceased family members had been similar, with convulsion and hyperthermia noted in two cases. This was the first breakthrough in recognizing MH as a heritable condition. 1960s: core-rod myopathy Shy and colleagues reported on a child with a non-progress

snippets.snippet_text: Medical considerations: Although it is plausible that affected individuals with variant(s) associated with RyR1 Ca 2+ leak may benefit from periodic dantrolene use, confirmation of channel leakiness may be difficult for a given variant. More preclinical research is necessary to confirm the functional impact of specific RYR1 variants, and likely impact of cytosolic free magnesium concentrations on dantrolene action in this population [ 119 , 120 ], in order to determine the safety and utility of dantrolene administration [ 36 ] with the potential for a future personalized health approach in the clinic. snippets.snippet_text: MH (MIM# 145600) is a potentially lethal hypermetabolic condition triggered by exposure of susceptible individuals to certain volatile anesthetics and muscle relaxants. MH-like events triggered by nonpharmacologic factors (high environmental and body temperature, stress) have also been reported [ 23 , 24 ]. With incomplete penetrance of MH susceptibility (~ 50%) and no common RYR1 causative variant, the diagnostic test for MH susceptibility is the in vitro caffeine–halothane contracture test (IVCT), which determines contracture thresholds. The IVCT requires an open biopsy to obtain sufficient fresh skeletal muscle tissue and may yield false-negative results [ 25 ]. Approximately 50% of MH-susceptible individuals exhibit cores on biopsy whereas others, without a history of myopathy prior to an MH episode (MH trait only), do not [ 8 , 26 , 27 ]. It is therefore challenging to rule out MH susceptibility in individuals with pathogenic RYR1 missense variants, and this is compounded by the fact that susceptible individuals do not always exhibit symptoms following initi

snippets.snippet_text: A homozygous and RyR1-null, dyspedic mouse model has also been established [ 89 ]. Although dyspedic mice die at birth owing to asphyxia resulting from skeletal muscle paralysis, this model has been successfully used to investigate components of EC coupling [ 90 ]. An MH mouse model had also been developed with the p.Arg163Cys RYR1 variant. In the homozygous state, the variant is embryonically lethal whereas the heterozygous form survives and exhibits halothane hypersensitivity [ 91 ]. However, there is no histopathology associated with this model [ 92 ], suggesting it is a valuable tool for researching MH but perhaps less so for RYR1 -RM. Alternatively, a severe homozygous zebrafish RYR1 -RM model ( relatively relaxed ) has been established which resembles RYR1 -related MmD [ 93 ]. This has proven useful for conducting high-throughput drug screening, and studies, using this model, provided rationale for the first RYR1 -RM clinical trial [ 50 ]. High-throughput drug screening, especially using the relatively relaxed zebrafish model but also other te

More specifically, in KDS, patients are characterised by myopathic and facial dysmorphia, musculoskeletal abnormalities, and susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia (MH) [ 1 , 7 , 8 ]. snippets.snippet_text: In two patients, episodes were recurrent, with severe multisystem involvement and sequelae. RyR1-mediated calcium signalling plays an important role in normal pancreatic function but has also been critically implicated in the pathophysiology of acute pancreatitis, particularly in bile acid- and ethanol-induced forms. Findings from relevant animal models indicate that pancreatic damage in these conditions may be ameliorated through administration of the specific RyR1 antagonist dantrolene and other compounds modifying pancreatic metabolism including calcium signalling. These observations suggest that patients with RYR1 gain-of-function variants may be at increased risk of developing acute pancreatitis, a condition which should therefore be considered in the health surveillance of such individuals.

snippets.snippet_text: Despite its expression in a wide range of tissues, non-skeletal muscle manifestations associated with RYR1 mutations have only been rarely reported. Here, we report three patients with a diagnosis of Central Core Disease (CCD), King-Denborough Syndrome (KDS) and Malignant Hyperthermia Susceptibility (MHS), respectively, who in addition to their (putative) RYR1-related disorder also developed symptoms and signs of acute pancreatitis. snippets.snippet_text: Physiologic contracture testing for MH susceptibility has not been reported in KDS. A young boy with KDS underwent muscle biopsy evaluation at age 3 years that documented an abnormal contracture response to halothane, indicating MH susceptibility. Histopathology demonstrated small type II fibers associated with type I hypertrophy. Contracture testing of muscle obtained from the patient's mother was positive, while a sibling's test was negative. This case is the first to demonstrate susceptibility to MH with KDS by using physiologic contracture testing. The presence of positive MH results in both the patient and his mother suggest one of the following: (1) KDS may be part of the spectrum of autosomal dominantly inherited MH; (2) the locus for MH and for KDS may be linked closely and inherited concurrently,
snippets.article_title: King-Denborough syndrome: contracture testing and literature review.

snippets.snippet_text: Neurology workup revealed the presence of a known causative ryanodine receptor (RYR1) mutation for MH, c.7522C>T; p.R2508C. Furthermore, the neurology workup diagnosed the child with King-Denborough syndrome (KDS). This particular mutation has never been documented in a patient with KDS. Atypical presentation of MH is more likely in patients with RYR1-related myopathy. A high index of suspicion for MH in children with myopathy is important. The MH hotline was helpful in the management of this patient when it was called after the initial dose of dantrolene. A neurology consult was essential for the diagnosis of KDS and future care.
snippets.article_title: Intraoperative Presentation of Malignant Hyperthermia (Confirmed by RYR1 Gene Mutation, c.7522C>T; p.R2508C) Leads to Diagnosis of King-Denborough Syndrome in a Child With Hypotonia and Dysmorphic Features: A Case Report.

snippets.snippet_text: He had some physical signs of KDS, e.g. pectus excavatum, low-set ears, malar hypoplasia, micrognathia, ptosis and down-slanting palpebral fissures. Moreover, his mother and maternal grand-uncle had medical history of MH. Therefore, he was diagnosed as KDS by pediatricians. All of the preoperative examinations, including serum creatine phosphokinase level, are normal. Previous 15 case-reports suggest that in KDS patients MH might be triggered by volatile anesthetics. To avoid the trigger, we maintained the general anesthesia with propofol, fentanyl and vecuronium. During perioperative period, his body temperature was 36.3-38.1 degrees C, and no symptom of MH was observed. It is rare that a diagnosis of KDS is made preoperatively since the MH-induction is involved in the criteria of this syndrome. In the anesthesia of patients who are suspected of KDS from their characteristic features or familial histories, an anesthesiologist should pay attention to prevent MH. The total intravenous anesthesia method appears useful for the management of KDS.
snippets.article_title: [Anesthetic management of the King-Denborough syndrome].

snippets.snippet_text: A 2-year-old boy was scheduled for cryptorchidopexy. He had some physical signs of KDS, e.g. pectus excavatum, low-set ears, malar hypoplasia, micrognathia, ptosis and down-slanting palpebral fissures. Moreover, his mother and maternal grand-uncle had medical history of MH. Therefore, he was diagnosed as KDS by pediatricians. All of the preoperative examinations, including serum creatine phosphokinase level, are normal. Previous 15 case-reports suggest that in KDS patients MH might be triggered by volatile anesthetics. To avoid the trigger, we maintained the general anesthesia with propofol, fentanyl and vecuronium. During perioperative period, his body temperature was 36.3-38.1 degrees C, and no symptom of MH was observed. It is rare that a diagnosis of KDS is made preoperatively since the MH-induction is involved in the criteria of this syndrome. In the anesthesia of patients who are suspected of KDS from their characteristic features or familial histories, an anesthesiologist should pay attention to prevent MH. The total intravenous anesthesia method appears useful for the management of KDS.
snippets.article_title: [Anesthetic management of the King-Denborough syndrome].

snippets.snippet_text: Inheritance in humans appears to be autosomal dominant with variable penetrance. Patients with MH rarely have physical or laboratory signs of muscle disease. However, scattered case reports and investigations of individuals with known myopathies and other muscle related problems, such as acute rhabdomyolysis or idiopathic persistently elevated creatine kinase, suggest a possible association of MH with a variety of neuromuscular diseases and stress syndromes. This association is very strong in the case of central core disease (CCD) where it is supported by clinical and laboratory evidence, including the proximity of the CCD gene to the ryanodine receptor gene on chromosome 19.
snippets.article_title: Malignant hyperthermia and neuromuscular disease.

snippets.snippet_text: Her KDS resulted in chronic respiratory failure. She had a permanent tracheostomy and required overnight ventilatory support for the previous two years. She had three admissions during her pregnancy, one for pneumonia and two for preterm labour. Labour was induced at 37 weeks. Her labour was managed in the operating room where a "clean" anesthesia machine was ready. Cooling aids and a MH emergency kit were immediately available. Intravenous access, an arterial line and a lumbar epidural catheter were inserted before induction of labour. Ropivacaine 0.08% + fentanyl 2 microg x mL(-1) were used for patient-controlled epidural analgesia. After 6.5 hr of labour the patient required ventilation. An outlet forceps was performed for delivery. Postpartum, she was ventilated overnight in the intensive care unit. The use of epidural analgesia, close monitoring and collaboration between the various disciplines were important in achieving a safe and uneventful labour in this high-risk parturient.
snippets.article_title: Anesthetic management of a ventilator-dependent parturient with the King-Denborough syndrome.

snippets.snippet_text: As adequate metabolic studies were not available at the time of the crisis he was referred for confirmation of the malignant hyperthermia (MH) status. Muscle tension studies confirmed the presence of MH. The patient's mother and father were subsequently tested and the mother was found to be MH positive, the father MH negative.
snippets.article_title: Dominantly inherited malignant hyperthermia (MH) in the King-Denborough syndrome.

snippets.snippet_text: These disorders include central core disease, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, myotonia congenita, myotonic dystrophy, nonspecific myopathies, and King-Denborough syndrome. In order to assess the anesthetic risk of MH in the neuromuscular population, we performed halothane and caffeine contracture testing for MH susceptibility on biopsied muscle removed from 25 consecutive neuromuscular patients during diagnostic evaluation. Positive contracture tests were found in 7 of 18 patients with myopathic disorders and 3 of 7 patients with neurogenic disorders. Two of our patients had anesthetic events suggesting MH. These findings suggest that myopathic and neuropathic disorders share pathogenic mechanisms with MH, resulting in positive contracture tests and possibly leading to clinical events during anesthesia. Although there is controversy regarding the interpretatio

MH was diagnosed and dantrolene i.v. was administered. Her maximum esophageal temperature was 40.2 degrees C. ETco2 and temperature returned to baseline values after dantrolene administration. Creatine phosphokinase (CK) level was 252 U.l-1 preoperatively, and 1690 U.l-1 next day. Case 2 was a year-and-9-month-old boy undergoing accessory ear resection. Anesthesia was induced with sevoflurane and nitrous oxide in oxygen. His trachea was intubated with an aid of vecuronium. Forty minutes after administration of sevoflurane his temperature rose to 38.6 degrees C with heart rate 191 bpm and Spo2 93%, and muscle rigidity of legs. MH was diagnosed and dantrolene was administered. His highest temperature was 39.3 degrees C and was reduced promptly after dantrolene. Postoperatively he was noted to have downslanting palpebral fissures, micrognathia, low set ears, and a single crease of the fifth finger and diagnosed as King syndrome which is reported to have association with MH. messages.content: You are a clinical evidence synthesis assistant. reason carefully about causality and therapeutic intent before classifying a claim. Use only the provided snippets and claim groups, cite every snippet you rely on, and avoid inferring new facts.

CONTEXT
Condition: King denborough
Related terms: King Denborough syndrome, King syndrome
You are given ranked evidence snippets grouped by drug. Higher snippet_score and lower article_rank indicate stronger evidence.
Each claim_group bundles snippets about the same drug or drug class.

LEGEND
- snippet_id: Stable identifier for citation.
- snippet_score: Higher values reflect stronger evidence based on article quality and cues.
- article_rank: Lower numbers indicate higher-priority articles in our search.
- cues: Keywords that influenced initial classification (risk/safety); verify them before accepting.
- claim_group_id: Use this when describing which evidence you aggregated.

INSTRUCTIONS
1. Determine whether each drug is described as a trigger/risk, a safe option, a therapy/mitigation, or inconclusive.
2. Reason about causality: do not label a drug as risk when it is merely co-administered; note when it is the therapy (e.g., dantrolene).
3. Merge snippets that support the same conclusion into one claim and cite every snippet_id you rely on.
4. If snippets conflict, create separate claims and explain the disagreement in the summaries/notes.
5. Classification must be risk, safety, or uncertain. Use uncertain when evidence is mixed or insufficient.
6. Provide short key_points (1–2 sentences) explaining the rationale drawn from each snippet.
7. Confidence should reflect strength and agreement of evidence.
8. Do not introduce new drugs or facts not present in the snippets.
9. Return only valid JSON matching the schema below.

   snippet: The purification of RyR1 Ca 2+ release channels in 1988 [ 4 ] and the subsequent discovery in 1991 of pathogenic RYR1 variants [ 5 ] led to the association of impaired Ca 2+ homeostasis with malignant hyperthermia (MH) susceptibility (MIM # 145600) [ 6 ]. MH is a potentially fatal disorder of skeletal muscle Ca 2+ regulation. MH episodes are triggered by exposure to certain volatile anesthetics (e.g., sevoflurane, desflurane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (succinylcholine). MH episodes are characterized by uncontrolled muscle hypermetabolism, with a clinical presentation including hypercapnia, sinus tachycardia, masseter muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia [ 5 , 7 ]. Guidelines from the European Malignant Hyperthermia Group (EMHG) and Malignant Hyperthermia Association of the United States (MHAUS) continue to inform the use of anesthetic drugs in individuals susceptible to MH [ 8 , 9 ].    snippet: Additional histopathological features of CCD include increased internal and central nuclei, presence of rods, minimal to moderate endomysial fibrosis, increased fatty tissue and connective tissue infiltration, Z-line streaming, sarcomeric disorganization, fiber size variation, and predominance of type 1 fibers [ 79 ]. 1960s: malignant hyperthermia In 1960, Michael Denborough and Roger Lovell described a case in which a young man nearly died following general anesthesia procedure with halothane for a compound fracture of the tibia and fibula [ 80 ]. There had been ten deaths attributable to general anesthesia, specifically ethyl chloride and ether, in the proband’s family. The pattern of inheritance was similar to an incomplete penetrant dominant gene or genes [ 81 ]. Available medical records showed that the course of events in the deceased family members had been similar, with convulsion and hyperthermia noted in two cases. This was the first breakthrough in recognizing MH as a heritable condition. 1960s: core-rod myopathy Shy and colleagues reported on a child with a non-progress

messages.content: You are a clinical evidence synthesis assistant. reason carefully about causality and therapeutic intent before classifying a claim. Use only the provided snippets and claim groups, cite every snippet you rely on, and avoid inferring new facts.

CONTEXT
Condition: King denborough
Related terms: King Denborough syndrome, King syndrome
You are given ranked evidence snippets grouped by drug. Higher snippet_score and lower article_rank indicate stronger evidence.
Each claim_group bundles snippets about the same drug or drug class.

LEGEND
- snippet_id: Stable identifier for citation.
- snippet_score: Higher values reflect stronger evidence based on article quality and cues.
- article_rank: Lower numbers indicate higher-priority articles in our search.
- cues: Keywords that influenced initial classification (risk/safety); verify them before accepting.
- claim_group_id: Use this when describing which evidence you aggregated.

INSTRUCTIONS
1. Determine whether each drug is described as a trigger/risk, a safe option, a therapy/mitigation, or inconclusive.
2. Reason about causality: do not label a drug as risk when it is merely co-administered; note when it is the therapy (e.g., dantrolene).
3. Merge snippets that support the same conclusion into one claim and cite every snippet_id you rely on.
4. If snippets conflict, create separate claims and explain the disagreement in the summaries/notes.
5. Classification must be risk, safety, or uncertain. Use uncertain when evidence is mixed or insufficient.
6. Provide short key_points (1–2 sentences) explaining the rationale drawn from each snippet.
7. Confidence should reflect strength and agreement of evidence.
8. Do not introduce new drugs or facts not present in the snippets.
9. Return only valid JSON matching the schema below.

   snippet: MH (MIM# 145600) is a potentially lethal hypermetabolic condition triggered by exposure of susceptible individuals to certain volatile anesthetics and muscle relaxants. MH-like events triggered by nonpharmacologic factors (high environmental and body temperature, stress) have also been reported [ 23 , 24 ]. With incomplete penetrance of MH susceptibility (~ 50%) and no common RYR1 causative variant, the diagnostic test for MH susceptibility is the in vitro caffeine–halothane contracture test (IVCT), which determines contracture thresholds. The IVCT requires an open biopsy to obtain sufficient fresh skeletal muscle tissue and may yield false-negative results [ 25 ]. Approximately 50% of MH-susceptible individuals exhibit cores on biopsy whereas others, without a history of myopathy prior to an MH episode (MH trait only), do not [ 8 , 26 , 27 ].    snippet: A homozygous and RyR1-null, dyspedic mouse model has also been established [ 89 ]. Although dyspedic mice die at birth owing to asphyxia resulting from skeletal muscle paralysis, this model has been successfully used to investigate components of EC coupling [ 90 ]. An MH mouse model had also been developed with the p.Arg163Cys RYR1 variant. In the homozygous state, the variant is embryonically lethal whereas the heterozygous form survives and exhibits halothane hypersensitivity [ 91 ]. However, there is no histopathology associated with this model [ 92 ], suggesting it is a valuable tool for researching MH but perhaps less so for RYR1 -RM. Alternatively, a severe homozygous zebrafish RYR1 -RM model ( relatively relaxed ) has been established which resembles RYR1 -related MmD [ 93 ]. This has proven useful for conducting high-throughput drug screening, and studies, using this model, provided rationale for the first RYR1 -RM clinical trial [ 50 ]. snippets.snippet_text: Medical considerations: Although it is plausible that affected individuals with variant(s) associated with RyR1 Ca 2+ leak may benefit from periodic dantrolene use, confirmation of channel leakiness may be difficult for a given variant. More preclinical research is necessary to confirm the functional impact of specific RYR1 variants, and likely impact of cytosolic free magnesium concentrations on dantrolene action in this population [ 119 , 120 ], in order to determine the safety and utility of dantrolene administration [ 36 ] with the potential for a future personalized health approach in the clinic. Rycals Rycals are a class of benzothiazepine-derived Ca 2+ channel stabilizers that have been developed by ARMGO Pharma Inc. (Tarrytown, NY) for chronic heart failure, cardiac arrhythmia, and catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia [ 121 ]. snippets.snippet_text: MH (MIM# 145600) is a potentially lethal hypermetabolic condition triggered by exposure of susceptible individuals to certain volatile anesthetics and muscle relaxants. MH-like events triggered by nonpharmacologic factors (high environmental and body temperature, stress) have also been reported [ 23 , 24 ]. With incomplete penetrance of MH susceptibility (~ 50%) and no common RYR1 causative variant, the diagnostic test for MH susceptibility is the in vitro caffeine–halothane contracture test (IVCT), which determines contracture thresholds. The IVCT requires an open biopsy to obtain sufficient fresh skeletal muscle tissue and may yield false-negative results [ 25 ]. messages.content: You are a clinical evidence synthesis assistant. reason carefully about causality and therapeutic intent before classifying a claim. Use only the provided snippets and claim groups, cite every snippet you rely on, and avoid inferring new facts.

CONTEXT
Condition: King denborough
Related terms: King Denborough syndrome, King syndrome
You are given ranked evidence snippets grouped by drug. Higher snippet_score and lower article_rank indicate stronger evidence.
Each claim_group bundles snippets about the same drug or drug class.

LEGEND
- snippet_id: Stable identifier for citation.
- snippet_score: Higher values reflect stronger evidence based on article quality and cues.
- article_rank: Lower numbers indicate higher-priority articles in our search.
- cues: Keywords that influenced initial classification (risk/safety); verify them before accepting.
- claim_group_id: Use this when describing which evidence you aggregated.

INSTRUCTIONS
1. Determine whether each drug is described as a trigger/risk, a safe option, a therapy/mitigation, or inconclusive.
2. Reason about causality: do not label a drug as risk when it is merely co-administered; note when it is the therapy (e.g., dantrolene).
3. Merge snippets that support the same conclusion into one claim and cite every snippet_id you rely on.
4. If snippets conflict, create separate claims and explain the disagreement in the summaries/notes.
5. Classification must be risk, safety, or uncertain. Use uncertain when evidence is mixed or insufficient.
6. Provide short key_points (1–2 sentences) explaining the rationale drawn from each snippet.
7. Confidence should reflect strength and agreement of evidence.
8. Do not introduce new drugs or facts not present in the snippets.
9. Return only valid JSON matching the schema below.

RyR1-mediated calcium signalling plays an important role in normal pancreatic function but has also been critically implicated in the pathophysiology of acute pancreatitis, particularly in bile acid- and ethanol-induced forms. Findings from relevant animal models indicate that pancreatic damage in these conditions may be ameliorated through administration of the specific RyR1 antagonist dantrolene and other compounds modifying pancreatic metabolism including calcium signalling. These observations suggest that patients with RYR1 gain-of-function variants may be at increased risk of developing acute pancreatitis, a condition which should therefore be considered in the health surveillance of such individuals.

snippets.snippet_text: It manifests as a hypermetabolic response resulting in tachycardia, tachypnea, hyperthermia, hypercapnia, acidosis, muscle rigidity and rhabdomyolysis. An increase in the end-tidal carbon dioxide is one of the earliest diagnostic signs. Dantrolene sodium is effective in the management of MH, and should be available whenever general anesthesia is administered. This review also aims to highlight the genetics and pathology of MH, along with its association with various inherited myopathy syndromes like central core disease, multi-mini core disease, Native-American myopathy, and King-Denborough syndrome.

messages.content: You are a clinical evidence synthesis assistant. reason carefully about causality and therapeutic intent before classifying a claim. Use only the provided snippets and claim groups, cite every snippet you rely on, and avoid inferring new facts.

CONTEXT
Condition: King denborough
Related terms: King Denborough syndrome, King syndrome
You are given ranked evidence snippets grouped by drug. Higher snippet_score and lower article_rank indicate stronger evidence.
Each claim_group bundles snippets about the same drug or drug class.

LEGEND
- snippet_id: Stable identifier for citation.
- snippet_score: Higher values reflect stronger evidence based on article quality and cues.
- article_rank: Lower numbers indicate higher-priority articles in our search.
- cues: Keywords that influenced initial classification (risk/safety); verify them before accepting.
- claim_group_id: Use this when describing which evidence you aggregated.

INSTRUCTIONS
1. Determine whether each drug is described as a trigger/risk, a safe option, a therapy/mitigation, or inconclusive.
2. Reason about causality: do not label a drug as risk when it is merely co-administered; note when it is the therapy (e.g., dantrolene).
3. Merge snippets that support the same conclusion into one claim and cite every snippet_id you rely on.
4. If snippets conflict, create separate claims and explain the disagreement in the summaries/notes.
5. Classification must be risk, safety, or uncertain. Use uncertain when evidence is mixed or insufficient.
6. Provide short key_points (1–2 sentences) explaining the rationale drawn from each snippet.
7. Confidence should reflect strength and agreement of evidence.
8. Do not introduce new drugs or facts not present in the snippets.
9. Return only valid JSON matching the schema below.

SCHEMA
{
  "condition": "string",
  "claims": [
    {
      "claim_id": "string",
      "classification": "risk | safety | uncertain",
      "drug_classes": ["string"],
      "drugs": ["string"],
      "summary": "string",
      "confidence": "low | medium | high",
      "supporting_evidence": [
        {
          "snippet_id": "string",
          "pmid": "string",
          "article_title": "string",
          "key_points": ["string"],
          "notes": "string"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

SAMPLE RESPONSE
{

    {
      "claim_id": "risk:depolarising-neuromuscular-blockers",
      "classification": "risk",
      "drug_classes": ["depolarising neuromuscular blocker"],
      "drugs": ["succinylcholine"],
      "summary": "Succinylcholine can precipitate malignant hyperthermia episodes in susceptible patients.",
      "confidence": "medium",
      "supporting_evidence": [
        {
          "snippet_id": "11111111-1",
          "pmid": "11111111",
          "article_title": "Safety considerations for neuromuscular blockade in dystrophinopathies",
          "key_points": ["Snippet describes malignant hyperthermia crisis after succinylcholine"],
          "notes": "Classification is risk because the snippet links succinylcholine exposure with the event."
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

CAUTION

1. snippet_id: 27
   article_pmid: 11345752
   article_title: [Anesthetic management of the King-Denborough syndrome].
   drug: propofol
   classification: risk
   score: 2.40
   article_rank: 8
   source_url: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11345752/
   cues: avoid, mh, trigger, triggered
   snippet: A 2-year-old boy was scheduled for cryptorchidopexy. He had some physical signs of KDS, e.g. pectus excavatum, low-set ears, malar hypoplasia, micrognathia, ptosis and down-slanting palpebral fissures. Moreover, his mother and maternal grand-uncle had medical history of MH. Therefore, he was diagnosed as KDS by pediatricians. All of the preoperative examinations, including serum creatine phosphokinase level, are normal. Previous 15 case-reports suggest that in KDS patients MH might be triggered by volatile anesthetics. To avoid the trigger, we maintained the general anesthesia with propofol, fentanyl and vecuronium. During perioperative period, his body temperature was 36.3-38.1 degrees C, and no symptom of MH was observed. It is rare that a diagnosis of KDS is made preoperatively since the MH-induction is involved in the criteria of this syndrome. In the anesthesia of patients who are suspected of KDS from their characteristic features or familial histories, an anesthesiologist should pay attention to prevent MH. The total intravenous anesthesia method appears useful for the management of KDS.

   article_pmid: 2907859
   article_title: King-Denborough syndrome: contracture testing and literature review.
   drug: halothane
   classification: risk
   score: 2.30
   article_rank: 6
   source_url: https://doi.org/10.1016/0887-8994(86)90013-5
   cues: mh
   snippet: Physiologic contracture testing for MH susceptibility has not been reported in KDS. A young boy with KDS underwent muscle biopsy evaluation at age 3 years that documented an abnormal contracture response to halothane, indicating MH susceptibility. Histopathology demonstrated small type II fibers associated with type I hypertrophy. Contracture testing of muscle obtained from the patient's mother was positive, while a sibling's test was negative. This case is the first to demonstrate susceptibility to MH with KDS by using physiologic contracture testing. The presence of positive MH results in both the patient and his mother suggest one of the following: (1) KDS may be part of the spectrum of autosomal dominantly inherited MH; (2) the locus for MH and for KDS may be linked closely and inherited concurrently,
4. snippet_id: 29
   article_pmid: 12826552
   article_title: Anesthetic management of a ventilator-dependent parturient with the King-Denborough syndrome.
   drug: ropivacaine
   classification: risk
   score: 2.05
   article_rank: 12
   source_url: https://doi.org/10.1007/BF03018646
   cues: mh, risk, safe
   snippet: Her KDS resulted in chronic respiratory failure. She had a permanent tracheostomy and required overnight ventilatory support for the previous two years. She had three admissions during her pregnancy, one for pneumonia and two for preterm labour. Labour was induced at 37 weeks. Her labour was managed in the operating room where a "clean" anesthesia machine was ready. Cooling aids and a MH emergency kit were immediately available. Intravenous access, an arterial line and a lumbar epidural catheter were inserted before induction of labour. Ropivacaine 0.08% + fentanyl 2 microg x mL(-1) were used for patient-controlled epidural analgesia. After 6.5 hr of labour the patient required ventilation. An outlet forceps was performed for delivery. Postpartum, she was ventilated overnight in the intensive care unit. The use of epidural analgesia, close monitoring and collaboration between the various disciplines were important in achieving a safe and uneventful labour in this high-risk parturient.

   article_pmid: 27918309
   article_title: Intraoperative Presentation of Malignant Hyperthermia (Confirmed by RYR1 Gene Mutation, c.7522C>T; p.R2508C) Leads to Diagnosis of King-Denborough Syndrome in a Child With Hypotonia and Dysmorphic Features: A Case Report.
   drug: dantrolene
   classification: safety
   score: 2.00
   article_rank: 7
   source_url: https://doi.org/10.1213/XAA.0000000000000421
   cues: therapy-role:mh-therapy
   snippet: Neurology workup revealed the presence of a known causative ryanodine receptor (RYR1) mutation for MH, c.7522C>T; p.R2508C. Furthermore, the neurology workup diagnosed the child with King-Denborough syndrome (KDS). This particular mutation has never been documented in a patient with KDS. Atypical presentation of MH is more likely in patients with RYR1-related myopathy. A high index of suspicion for MH in children with myopathy is important. The MH hotline was helpful in the management of this patient when it was called after the initial dose of dantrolene. A neurology consult was essential for the diagnosis of KDS and future care.

   snippet: Inheritance in humans appears to be autosomal dominant with variable penetrance. Patients with MH rarely have physical or laboratory signs of muscle disease. However, scattered case reports and investigations of individuals with known myopathies and other muscle related problems, such as acute rhabdomyolysis or idiopathic persistently elevated creatine kinase, suggest a possible association of MH with a variety of neuromuscular diseases and stress syndromes. This association is very strong in the case of central core disease (CCD) where it is supported by clinical and laboratory evidence, including the proximity of the CCD gene to the ryanodine receptor gene on chromosome 19.

snippets.snippet_text: A 2-year-old boy was scheduled for cryptorchidopexy. He had some physical signs of KDS, e.g. pectus excavatum, low-set ears, malar hypoplasia, micrognathia, ptosis and down-slanting palpebral fissures. Moreover, his mother and maternal grand-uncle had medical history of MH. Therefore, he was diagnosed as KDS by pediatricians. All of the preoperative examinations, including serum creatine phosphokinase level, are normal. Previous 15 case-reports suggest that in KDS patients MH might be triggered by volatile anesthetics. To avoid the trigger, we maintained the general anesthesia with propofol, fentanyl and vecuronium. During perioperative period, his body temperature was 36.3-38.1 degrees C, and no symptom of MH was observed. It is rare that a diagnosis of KDS is made preoperatively since the MH-induction is involved in the criteria of this syndrome. In the anesthesia of patients who are suspected of KDS from their characteristic features or familial histories, an anesthesiologist should pay attention to prevent MH. The total intravenous anesthesia method appears useful for the management of KDS.

snippets.snippet_text: Physiologic contracture testing for MH susceptibility has not been reported in KDS. A young boy with KDS underwent muscle biopsy evaluation at age 3 years that documented an abnormal contracture response to halothane, indicating MH susceptibility. Histopathology demonstrated small type II fibers associated with type I hypertrophy. Contracture testing of muscle obtained from the patient's mother was positive, while a sibling's test was negative. This case is the first to demonstrate susceptibility to MH with KDS by using physiologic contracture testing. The presence of positive MH results in both the patient and his mother suggest one of the following: (1) KDS may be part of the spectrum of autosomal dominantly inherited MH; (2) the locus for MH and for KDS may be linked closely and inherited concurrently,
snippets.article_title: King-Denborough syndrome: contracture testing and literature review.

snippets.snippet_text: Her KDS resulted in chronic respiratory failure. She had a permanent tracheostomy and required overnight ventilatory support for the previous two years. She had three admissions during her pregnancy, one for pneumonia and two for preterm labour. Labour was induced at 37 weeks. Her labour was managed in the operating room where a "clean" anesthesia machine was ready. Cooling aids and a MH emergency kit were immediately available. Intravenous access, an arterial line and a lumbar epidural catheter were inserted before induction of labour. Ropivacaine 0.08% + fentanyl 2 microg x mL(-1) were used for patient-controlled epidural analgesia. After 6.5 hr of labour the patient required ventilation. An outlet forceps was performed for delivery. Postpartum, she was ventilated overnight in the intensive care unit. The use of epidural analgesia, close monitoring and collaboration between the various disciplines were important in achieving a safe and uneventful labour in this high-risk parturient.
snippets.article_title: Anesthetic management of a ventilator-dependent parturient with the King-Denborough syndrome.

snippets.snippet_text: These disorders include central core disease, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, myotonia congenita, myotonic dystrophy, nonspecific myopathies, and King-Denborough syndrome. In order to assess the anesthetic risk of MH in the neuromuscular population, we performed halothane and caffeine contracture testing for MH susceptibility on biopsied muscle removed from 25 consecutive neuromuscular patients during diagnostic evaluation. Positive contracture tests were found in 7 of 18 patients with myopathic disorders and 3 of 7 patients with neurogenic disorders. Two of our patients had anesthetic events suggesting MH. These findings suggest that myopathic and neuropathic disorders share pathogenic mechanisms with MH, resulting in positive contracture tests and possibly leading to clinical events during anesthesia. Although there is controversy regarding the interpretatio

You are given ranked evidence snippets grouped by drug. Higher snippet_score and lower article_rank indicate stronger evidence.
Each claim_group bundles snippets about the same drug or drug class.

LEGEND
- snippet_id: Stable identifier for citation.
- snippet_score: Higher values reflect stronger evidence based on article quality and cues.
- article_rank: Lower numbers indicate higher-priority articles in our search.
- cues: Keywords that influenced initial classification (risk/safety); verify them before accepting.
- claim_group_id: Use this when describing which evidence you aggregated.

1. Determine whether each drug is described as a trigger/risk, a safe option, a therapy/mitigation, or inconclusive.
2. Reason about causality: do not label a drug as risk when it is merely co-administered; note when it is the therapy (e.g., dantrolene).
3. Merge snippets that support the same conclusion into one claim and cite every snippet_id you rely on.
4. If snippets conflict, create separate claims and explain the disagreement in the summaries/notes.
5. Classification must be risk, safety, or uncertain. Use uncertain when evidence is mixed or insufficient.
6. Provide short key_points (1–2 sentences) explaining the rationale drawn from each snippet.
7. Confidence should reflect strength and agreement of evidence.
8. Do not introduce new drugs or facts not present in the snippets.

snippets.snippet_text: Muscle rigidity of legs and the rise in temperature were noted. MH was diagnosed and dantrolene i.v. was administered. Her maximum esophageal temperature was 40.2 degrees C. ETco2 and temperature returned to baseline values after dantrolene administration. Creatine phosphokinase (CK) level was 252 U.l-1 preoperatively, and 1690 U.l-1 next day. Case 2 was a year-and-9-month-old boy undergoing accessory ear resection. Anesthesia was induced with sevoflurane and nitrous oxide in oxygen. His trachea was intubated with an aid of vecuronium. Forty minutes after administration of sevoflurane his temperature rose to 38.6 degrees C with heart rate 191 bpm and Spo2 93%, and muscle rigidity of legs. MH was diagnosed and dantrolene was administered. His highest temperature was 39.3 degrees C and was reduced promptly after dantrolene. Postoperatively he was noted to have downslanting palpebral fissures, micrognathia, low set ears, and a single crease of the fifth finger and diagnosed as King syndrome which is reported to have association with MH. Both patients had no history of anesthesia nor abnormal family history. Both of them were rescued with dantrolene and recovered without seque
snippets.article_title: [Two pediatric cases of malignant hyperthermia caused by sevoflurane].

claims.summary: Succinylcholine (a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker) is described as a trigger for malignant hyperthermia in individuals with RYR1-related susceptibility.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine receptor 1-related disorders: an historical perspective and proposal for a unified nomenclature.
key_points: The review states that MH episodes are triggered by exposure to certain volatile anesthetics and depolarizing muscle relaxants (succinylcholine).
MH is linked to pathogenic RYR1 variants and is characterized by uncontrolled muscle hypermetabolism.
supporting_evidence.notes: Classification as risk is based on explicit statement that depolarizing muscle relaxants (succinylcholine) trigger MH in RYR1-related disorders.

claims.summary: The source indicates that exposure to depolarizing muscle relaxants is associated with malignant hyperthermia episodes in RYR1-related conditions; the evidence specifically names depolarizing agents (succinylcholine) rather than all neuromuscular blockers.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine receptor 1-related disorders: an historical perspective and proposal for a unified nomenclature.
key_points: The review links impaired RyR1 Ca2+ regulation and pathogenic RYR1 variants with MH susceptibility.
It states MH episodes are triggered by certain volatile anesthetics and depolarizing muscle relaxants (succinylcholine).
supporting_evidence.notes: The snippet supports risk for depolarizing neuromuscular blockers; it does not provide evidence that non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers trigger MH, so the claim is framed at the class level with caution.

claims.summary: Volatile inhalational anesthetics (examples: sevoflurane, desflurane, halothane) are described as triggers for malignant hyperthermia in individuals with RYR1-related susceptibility.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine receptor 1-related disorders: an historical perspective and proposal for a unified nomenclature.
key_points: The review explicitly lists volatile anesthetics (e.g., sevoflurane, desflurane) among exposures that trigger MH episodes.
Guidelines (EMHG, MHAUS) are referenced regarding anesthetic drug use in MH-susceptible individuals.
supporting_evidence.notes: Direct statement in the review that volatile anesthetics trigger MH supports classification as risk.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine receptor 1-related disorders: an historical perspective and proposal for a unified nomenclature.
key_points: The same review passage reiterates that MH episodes are triggered by volatile anesthetics (including sevoflurane).
supporting_evidence.notes: Duplicate supporting text from the same source emphasizing volatile anesthetic triggers.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine receptor 1-related disorders: an historical perspective and proposal for a unified nomenclature.
key_points: The review again notes volatile anesthetics as MH triggers and references clinical features of MH.
Historical cases (e.g., halothane exposure) are described in the context of recognizing MH as heritable.
supporting_evidence.notes: Multiple passages in the same review consistently identify volatile anesthetics as MH triggers; snippet 6 provides historical example (halothane).

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine receptor 1-related disorders: an historical perspective and proposal for a unified nomenclature.
key_points: Historical case descriptions include severe reactions following halothane anesthesia that contributed to recognizing MH as heritable.
The passage links halothane exposure with fatal/near-fatal anesthesia-related events in affected families.
supporting_evidence.notes: Historical example (halothane) strengthens the association between volatile anesthetics and MH in this review.

claims.summary: Dantrolene is proposed as a potential therapeutic option for individuals with RYR1 variants that cause Ca2+ leak, but the source states that more preclinical research is needed to confirm functional impacts and determine safety and utility for periodic use.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine Receptor 1-Related Myopathies: Diagnostic and Therapeutic Approaches.
key_points: The review suggests it is plausible that individuals with RYR1 variants causing Ca2+ leak may benefit from periodic dantrolene use.

The authors state that confirmation of channel leakiness is difficult for some variants and that more preclinical research is necessary to determine safety and utility of dantrolene in this population.
supporting_evidence.notes: This evidence indicates therapeutic intent but highlights uncertainty and need for further research; therefore the claim is classified as uncertain with low confidence rather than as established safety/therapy.

claims.summary: Dantrolene is an effective treatment for malignant hyperthermia (MH) and is considered a mitigation strategy; its routine periodic use specifically for RYR1 variant carriers is plausible but not yet confirmed and requires further study.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine Receptor 1-Related Myopathies: Diagnostic and Therapeutic Approaches.
key_points: Authors state that affected individuals with variants associated with RyR1 Ca2+ leak may plausibly benefit from periodic dantrolene use, but note that confirmation of channel leakiness and the safety/utility of such administration require more preclinical research.
supporting_evidence.notes: This snippet supports dantrolene as a potential therapy but cautions that safety/utility for periodic use in RYR1-variant patients is unconfirmed; classification is safety because the drug is described as a therapeutic/mitigating agent rather than a trigger.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Malignant Hyperthermia.
key_points: States that dantrolene sodium is effective in the management of MH and should be available whenever general anesthesia is administered.
supporting_evidence.notes: This clinical review directly supports the role of dantrolene as the effective acute treatment for MH, reinforcing its classification as a mitigation/safety intervention for MH episodes that may occur in King-Denborough.

claims.summary: Neuromuscular blocking agents (muscle relaxants) are reported triggers of malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals, and MH is associated with syndromes such as King-Denborough.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine Receptor 1-Related Myopathies: Diagnostic and Therapeutic Approaches.
key_points: States that MH is a potentially lethal hypermetabolic condition triggered by exposure of susceptible individuals to certain volatile anesthetics and muscle relaxants.
supporting_evidence.notes: Direct statement that muscle relaxants can trigger MH in susceptible people; supports classification as risk.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Malignant Hyperthermia.
key_points: Review links MH to inherited myopathy syndromes including King-Denborough and describes clinical features of MH (rigidity, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis).
supporting_evidence.notes: Connects MH (which can be triggered by muscle relaxants) to King-Denborough, supporting relevance of the risk in this condition.

claims.summary: Volatile anesthetics (including halothane) are reported triggers of malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals; experimental models show halothane hypersensitivity linked to RYR1 variants.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine Receptor 1-Related Myopathies: Diagnostic and Therapeutic Approaches.
key_points: States that MH can be triggered by exposure to certain volatile anesthetics and that MH susceptibility is linked to RYR1 variants.
supporting_evidence.notes: Direct clinical statement that volatile anesthetics can trigger MH in susceptible individuals; supports risk classification.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine Receptor 1-Related Myopathies: Diagnostic and Therapeutic Approaches.
key_points: Reiterates that MH is triggered by volatile anesthetics and muscle relaxants and notes incomplete penetrance and diagnostic challenges for MH susceptibility.
supporting_evidence.notes: Reinforces the trigger relationship and highlights diagnostic uncertainty in identifying susceptible individuals.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Ryanodine Receptor 1-Related Myopathies: Diagnostic and Therapeutic Approaches.
key_points: Reports an MH mouse model with an RYR1 variant that exhibits halothane hypersensitivity in the heterozygous state, providing experimental evidence linking halothane exposure to MH phenotype.
supporting_evidence.notes: Provides animal-model evidence of halothane as a trigger in the context of RYR1 variants, supporting causal inference.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Malignant Hyperthermia.
key_points: Describes MH clinical features and notes dantrolene as effective treatment; places MH in context of triggers such as volatile anesthetics.
supporting_evidence.notes: Clinical review that links MH features and management with triggers including volatile anesthetics, further supporting risk classification.

claims.summary: Malignant hyperthermia (MH) in King–Denborough syndrome (KDS) is expected to develop upon exposure to volatile anaesthetic gases (e.g., isoflurane) or the depolarising neuromuscular blocker succinylcholine; these agents are therefore triggers to avoid or use with MH precautions.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Biallelic variants in RYR1 and STAC3 are predominant causes of King-Denborough Syndrome in an African cohort.
key_points: The article states MH is expected to develop upon administration of volatile anaesthetic gases (isoflurane) or succinylcholine in susceptible individuals.
The paper reports observed MH events in affected participants undergoing surgery, indicating clinical relevance of these triggers in this cohort.
supporting_evidence.notes: Classification as risk because the snippet explicitly links administration of isoflurane/succinylcholine with the expected development of MH in MH-susceptible patients with KDS.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Biallelic variants in RYR1 and STAC3 are predominant causes of King-Denborough Syndrome in an African cohort.
key_points: The text repeats that MH susceptibility is expected to be revealed upon administration of volatile anaesthetic gases or succinylcholine.
Surgical cases in the cohort included MH events, supporting the role of these agents as triggers.
supporting_evidence.notes: Supports the same conclusion; cited separately because it names succinylcholine explicitly in the context of MH risk.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Biallelic variants in RYR1 and STAC3 are predominant causes of King-Denborough Syndrome in an African cohort.
key_points: Authors state MH susceptibility is expected to develop on administration of volatile anaesthetic gases or succinylcholine.
The snippet notes MH events observed in surgical subsets of the cohort, implying clinical trigger-risk association.
supporting_evidence.notes: Additional support from same article for volatile anaesthetics as MH triggers.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Biallelic variants in RYR1 and STAC3 are predominant causes of King-Denborough Syndrome in an African cohort.
key_points: Again restates that volatile anaesthetic gases or succinylcholine can precipitate MH in susceptible individuals.
Notes that preventative protocols can be implemented when surgery is necessary to reduce MH risk.
supporting_evidence.notes: Reinforces the recommendation that exposure to these agents is a precipitating risk and that precautions are indicated.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Biallelic variants in RYR1 and STAC3 are predominant causes of King-Denborough Syndrome in an African cohort.
key_points: Describes KDS as characterised by susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia (MH).
Places MH susceptibility among core clinical features of KDS, supporting the biological plausibility of agent-triggered MH.
supporting_evidence.notes: Used to support that patients with KDS are MH-susceptible, which makes exposure to known MH triggers (volatile agents, succinylcholine) a clinical risk.

claims.summary: Dantrolene sodium is an effective therapy for malignant hyperthermia and should be available when general anaesthesia is administered to MH-susceptible patients (including those with King–Denborough syndrome).

supporting_evidence.article_title: Malignant Hyperthermia.
key_points: Dantrolene sodium is effective in the management of malignant hyperthermia and should be available whenever general anaesthesia is administered.
The review highlights the association of MH with inherited myopathies including King–Denborough syndrome, linking the therapeutic recommendation to this condition.
supporting_evidence.notes: Classification as safety because the snippet explicitly states dantrolene is an effective management for MH and recommends availability during general anaesthesia for at-risk patients.

claims.summary: Preclinical evidence suggests dantrolene (a RyR1 antagonist) may ameliorate pancreatic damage in models of bile acid- or ethanol-induced pancreatitis, and authors note RYR1 gain-of-function variants could increase pancreatitis risk in humans; dantrolene is therefore proposed as a potential mitigating agent, but human data are lacking.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Pancreatitis in RYR1-related disorders.
key_points: Animal model findings indicate pancreatic damage in certain forms of acute pancreatitis may be ameliorated by administration of the RyR1 antagonist dantrolene.
Authors suggest patients with RYR1 gain-of-function variants may be at increased risk of acute pancreatitis, and note dantrolene and other metabolic modifiers as potential ameliorative agents.
supporting_evidence.notes: Classified as safety (potential mitigation) but confidence is low because the evidence is preliminary (animal models and mechanistic inference) and does not provide direct human therapeutic data in KDS.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Pancreatitis in RYR1-related disorders.
key_points: Reports cases of pancreatitis in patients with RYR1-related disorders including King–Denborough syndrome, indicating a possible non-skeletal muscle manifestation in these disorders.
Notes the role of RyR1-mediated calcium signalling in pancreatic function, providing biological rationale for RyR1-targeted interventions.
supporting_evidence.notes: Used to support the relevance of RyR1 dysfunction to pancreatic disease in these disorders; does not directly report dantrolene treatment in humans, so contributes to mechanistic support only.

claims.summary: Volatile inhalational anesthetics (e.g., halothane) are associated with malignant hyperthermia (MH) susceptibility in patients with King-Denborough syndrome based on contracture testing and case reports.

supporting_evidence.article_title: King-Denborough syndrome: contracture testing and literature review.
key_points: A child with KDS had an abnormal contracture response to halothane on muscle testing, indicating MH susceptibility; the mother was also positive, supporting a genetic link.
Authors suggest KDS may lie within the spectrum of autosomal dominantly inherited MH or be genetically linked to MH.
supporting_evidence.notes: Direct physiologic contracture testing linked halothane exposure to MH susceptibility in a KDS patient, supporting classification as a risk.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Halothane-caffeine contracture testing in neuromuscular diseases.
key_points: Halothane and caffeine contracture testing found positive results among neuromuscular patients, with King-Denborough syndrome included among disorders tested.
Authors note that myopathic disorders (including KDS) can share pathogenic mechanisms with MH, potentially leading to clinical events during anesthesia.
supporting_evidence.notes: Adds broader evidence that halothane contracture testing is positive in KDS and related myopathies, reinforcing risk classification.

claims.summary: Total intravenous anesthesia using propofol has been used in KDS patients to avoid volatile anesthetic triggers and was associated with no perioperative MH in a reported case.

supporting_evidence.article_title: [Anesthetic management of the King-Denborough syndrome].
key_points: Because previous reports suggested volatile anesthetics may trigger MH in KDS, the team used total intravenous anesthesia with propofol (plus fentanyl and vecuronium) to avoid volatile agents.
In that perioperative period no signs of MH were observed.
supporting_evidence.notes: Case report documents propofol-based TIVA used successfully to avoid suspected volatile-triggered MH; classification as safety (safe option) is based on its deliberate use to prevent triggers rather than evidence of absolute safety.

claims.summary: Vecuronium was co-administered with propofol-based anesthesia in a KDS patient without precipitating MH in the reported case.

supporting_evidence.article_title: [Anesthetic management of the King-Denborough syndrome].
key_points: Vecuronium was used as part of a total intravenous anesthetic (with propofol and fentanyl) in a KDS patient to avoid volatile triggers.
No perioperative MH symptoms were observed during that case.
supporting_evidence.notes: Snippet only documents co-administration without MH; classification as safety (safe option) reflects absence of adverse event in this report and does not prove universal safety.

claims.summary: Epidural ropivacaine (with fentanyl) was used for labor analgesia in a ventilator-dependent woman with KDS and the labor/delivery was managed without MH events.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Anesthetic management of a ventilator-dependent parturient with the King-Denborough syndrome.
key_points: Ropivacaine with fentanyl was used for patient-controlled epidural analgesia during labor in a high-risk KDS patient, with a 'clean' anesthesia machine and MH preparations available.
The labor and delivery were uneventful with respect to MH, though the patient required ventilation during labor and close multidisciplinary management was emphasized.
supporting_evidence.notes: This single-case report shows successful use of epidural ropivacaine without MH; classified as safety (used safely in this context) but evidence is limited to one report.

claims.summary: Dantrolene was used in the intraoperative management of MH in a child who was subsequently diagnosed with KDS and RYR1 mutation; the case supports dantrolene's role as therapy for MH in this population.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Intraoperative Presentation of Malignant Hyperthermia (Confirmed by RYR1 Gene Mutation, c.7522C>T; p.R2508C) Leads to Diagnosis of King-Denborough Syndrome in a Child With Hypotonia and Dysmorphic Features: A Case Report.
key_points: An intraoperative MH episode occurred in a child who was later diagnosed with KDS and a causative RYR1 mutation; dantrolene was administered and the MH hotline was consulted after the initial dose.
Authors highlight the importance of suspicion for MH in children with myopathy and document the practical use of dantrolene in management.
supporting_evidence.notes: Snippet documents therapeutic use of dantrolene during an MH event in a patient with KDS; classification as safety reflects its role as treatment rather than as a risk factor.

claims.summary: Available snippet(s) discuss an association between neuromuscular diseases and MH susceptibility but do not provide direct evidence that neuromuscular blocking agents are triggers in KDS; the relationship to drugs is unclear from the provided text.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Malignant hyperthermia and neuromuscular disease.
key_points: The article notes an association between MH and various neuromuscular diseases, with particularly strong evidence for central core disease.
It states that patients with MH rarely have overt signs of muscle disease but that reports suggest links between MH and myopathies; it does not implicate neuromuscular blocking drugs as causes.
supporting_evidence.notes: Snippet addresses disease associations with MH rather than causal roles for neuromuscular blocking agents; therefore the evidence is insufficient to classify the drug class as a risk or safe option for KDS.

claims.summary: Muscle contracture testing shows MH susceptibility in neuromuscular disorders including King-Denborough, suggesting increased anesthetic risk in this population; however the provided snippets do not specifically implicate neuromuscular blocking agents as causal triggers.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Halothane-caffeine contracture testing in neuromuscular diseases.
key_points: The report lists King-Denborough syndrome among neuromuscular disorders tested for MH susceptibility using halothane and caffeine contracture testing.
Positive contracture tests were found in a proportion of patients with myopathic and neurogenic disorders, indicating MH susceptibility in these neuromuscular conditions.
supporting_evidence.notes: Supports that King-Denborough is associated with MH susceptibility but does not identify neuromuscular blocking agents as the specific trigger; therefore causality for neuromuscular blockers is uncertain.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Halothane-caffeine contracture testing in neuromuscular diseases.
key_points: Authors report two patients had anesthetic events suggesting MH and conclude myopathic and neuropathic disorders may share pathogenic mechanisms with MH, possibly leading to clinical events during anesthesia.
King-Denborough syndrome is explicitly included among the disorders examined.
supporting_evidence.notes: Reinforces that King-Denborough syndrome confers MH susceptibility during anesthesia but does not attribute events to neuromuscular blocking agents specifically; classification remains uncertain for that drug class.

claims.summary: Nitrous oxide was co-administered with sevoflurane in reported MH cases in patients later diagnosed with King syndrome, but the snippet does not provide evidence that nitrous oxide caused the MH events.

supporting_evidence.article_title: [Two pediatric cases of malignant hyperthermia caused by sevoflurane].
key_points: Case reports describe anesthesia induction with sevoflurane and nitrous oxide (case 2) followed by MH signs; dantrolene was effective.
The snippet notes sevoflurane administration temporally preceded the MH episodes; nitrous oxide was co-administered but causality is not attributed to it in the text.
supporting_evidence.notes: Because nitrous oxide was given alongside sevoflurane, and the article title/description attribute the events to sevoflurane, the evidence is insufficient to classify nitrous oxide as a trigger; therefore classification is uncertain and confidence is low.

claims.summary: Sevoflurane is reported to have precipitated malignant hyperthermia in two pediatric cases who were subsequently diagnosed with King (King-Denborough) syndrome; these events were treated successfully with dantrolene. Contracture testing data also indicate King-Denborough syndrome is associated with MH susceptibility.

supporting_evidence.article_title: [Two pediatric cases of malignant hyperthermia caused by sevoflurane].
key_points: A pediatric case developed MH signs (hypercapnia, high temperature, muscle rigidity) after induction/maintenance with sevoflurane; dantrolene reversed the episode.
The patient was later recognized to have features of King syndrome, which is reported to be associated with MH.
supporting_evidence.notes: This snippet provides a temporal association between sevoflurane exposure and an MH episode in a patient with King syndrome, supporting classification of sevoflurane as a risk in this context.

supporting_evidence.article_title: [Two pediatric cases of malignant hyperthermia caused by sevoflurane].
key_points: A second pediatric case developed MH 40 minutes after sevoflurane administration; dantrolene was effective and the child recovered.
Both reported patients had features consistent with King syndrome and no prior anesthesia or family history.
supporting_evidence.notes: Reiterates the reported causal relationship between sevoflurane exposure and MH in patients with King syndrome from the same case series.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Halothane-caffeine contracture testing in neuromuscular diseases.
key_points: King-Denborough syndrome is listed among neuromuscular disorders tested and shown to have MH susceptibility by halothane-caffeine contracture testing.
Positive contracture tests in neuromuscular disorders indicate a biological predisposition to MH during exposure to triggering anesthetics.
supporting_evidence.notes: Provides supporting physiologic evidence that King-Denborough syndrome confers susceptibility to MH with triggering anesthetics (e.g., volatile agents), strengthening the plausibility that sevoflurane precipitated the reported episodes.

supporting_evidence.article_title: Halothane-caffeine contracture testing in neuromuscular diseases.
key_points: Authors report that myopathic and neuropathic disorders may share pathogenic mechanisms with MH and that positive contracture tests may lead to clinical events during anesthesia.
King-Denborough syndrome is included in the disorders examined.
supporting_evidence.notes: Adds corroborating evidence that patients with King-Denborough syndrome are at risk of MH during exposure to known triggers such as volatile anesthetics; classification as risk is based on direct case reports plus physiologic testing data.
